I initially picked this game up because I thought the artstyle was cool and gritty. Now 100 hours later I understand that this game is not some hero's journey where the game tries to appear challenging through spongy enemies and terrible dialogue. No, this game makes it ABUNDANTLY clear that the odds are stacked against you by ripping away your precious heroes permanently when it so feels. It does not matter how leveled they are or what gear you give them to improve, there is ALWAYS a chance that your heroes die. 

Although the challenge of this game is immense, I do find that it is fair. Yes the enemies hit very hard, but if you build your characters out properly, you can hit them back just as hard if not harder. For example, if there is an enemy that completely negates 80% of damage taken, some heroes have skills that fully punch right through that for full damage, every time. Darkest Dungeon very much rewards smart tactics (unless the random dice rolls don't land in your favor). 

Darkest Dungeon also focuses in on the concept of risk/reward. For anyone considering buying the game, there is a torch that you can keep lit, and it grants you a myriad of bonuses. It's presented as this beacon of hope for your heroes lore-wise. However, you do not have to keep this torch lit. If you let it go out, the fights get harder, which put your heroes in danger, but you also get significantly more rewards for doing so. 

There is so much that this game has to offer, and I am honestly shocked that I had not heard of it before I bought it myself. I genuinely have not been challenged by a game this much since the first time I played Dark Souls. I love this game with all my heart. If there is anyone out there that is unsure if this game will be worth the money, let me assure you beyond a shadow of a doubt that it is.

For example, I finished Metro Exodus Best Ending with Ranger Hardcore difficulty and it's a pretty balanced difficulty for me, since the enemies are greater in intelligence, but they still have the same limitations of the player.

On the other hand, Darkest Dungeon Stygian Difficulty just lazily buffed the enemies HP, buffed the enemies attack, and add 1 new simple feature which is death limits. No shame to the developer, but for a game that glazed itself to be the "darkest", it could at least try to be more creative in making the enemies harder instead of just increasing the enemies stats with no thoughts behind it.

I was hoping for a more mental gymnastic game like Metro Exodus Ranger Hardcore, not just this silly RNG stuff.

Before any of you accuse me of not using any tactics, I used up every single tactics I could develop from what the game teaches you:
1) I made sure my light levels at the highest level possible in every single battle.
2) I made sure my team composition is as balanced and using their full personal preference as possible. Even if the team I got were fully RNG.
3) I made sure all the items I bring for my adventure is sufficient and befit every single situation as if I'm Goblin Slayer. Even having trinkets based on my team composition.
4) I made sure all my actions in battle are calculated.

After using all of that, I've used up all of the skills I could find as a beginner of Darkest Dungeon, but an experienced player at challenging game in general. Yet, it's not enough and still comes down to pure luck.

I definitely have a bit of a love hate relationship with this game.  First off, the classes and combat are really well designed. I'm not a big Lovecraft fan, but the themes are extremely well done and fit the game amazingly well. The game studio's name "Red Hook" is actually a Lovecraft reference itself, so you know these guys are really passionate about the material.

The turn-based combat system is great. Character position matters. Abilities can only be used in certain positions making for lots of possible team compositions based on what classes you choose and what positions you put them in.  Positioning also creates a lot of frustrations though, since several enemies will move your characters around and surprise mechanics may completely shuffle your team out of order at the start of combat.  An S tier team comp when in an exact order can easily become an F tier team when shuffled at the start of combat, causing you to lose a few early turns to fix your order or continue with it sub-optimally.  It's important to consider that and have some flexibility in your team for when you inevitably get moved or shuffled around.

The game really punishes you for lack of game knowledge, which is why the game is most difficult at the start and when playing blind without guides.  All the bosses have a mechanic that you need to understand and build your team around.  Not being prepared for it will often cause things to go south pretty quickly.  Earlier difficulties are a little more forgiving though, so it's up to you to quickly formulate ideas for an optimal strategy and remember to bring a good set-up when you take on the more difficult variations of those bosses later.  

My biggest gripe with the game is just that there is a lot of repetition.  You'll enter the same dungeons, fight the same kinds of monsters, fight increasingly difficult variations of bosses and then eventually take on the darkest dungeon.  Your characters and teams will die as you learn through a bit of trial and error to develop your game knowledge.  That's all fine, but having to re-level characters again, going through the same minimally randomized dungeons, just starts to feel like too much of a grind after a while, and not always particularly fun.

With all that being said, I still enjoyed the game overall.  If you like difficult turn-based games, then it's definitely worth playing through a run.

Darkest Dungeon is a roguelike, side-scrolling dungeon crawler which tries and successfully makes suffering fun. 

Picture this, a turnbased RPG in which your party of four has a random encounter with some spiders, pretty typical right? Well imagine that the spiders go first, they instantly posion your healer and kill them, they then shoot web at your melee guy pushing him to the back of your line meaning you have to waste turns putting him back to the front so he can attack, during all this your other two party members get so stressed that one starts attacking randomly and the other just dies of a heart attack basically ruining the run. That's darkest dungeon and it happens often. 

The fun is overcoming the odds with a rag tag bunch of killers who manage to get out of the dungeon on the overside. The game priorities placements and positioning as the way you set up your team can be life or death. In the down time between dungeon crawls you can build up your little town, go to the pub and upgrade your team (only for them to die next round losing all your upgrades) the fun isn't about getting to the end, it's the balance of trying to build a team that can get there only for them to all freakout because you didn't buy enough torches. 

Simply put if you enjoy going at a snails pace, taking it slow and really looking over the minute details and feeling that immensely satisfying feeling of over coming a difficult dungeon then this game is for you, often regarded as a classic and for good reason, this is a suffering simulator and call me a masochist but I love it.

It's not easy and failure is expected, and I appreciate that in a game's design when it's up front. 

However, this is not a game that respects your time or a particularly large amount of freedom of choice. There are better hero classes than others, there are trinkets you'll never use despite them being Legendary, and there are fights that your party are completely over-tuned for yet you lose because of dungeon balance. It's the last problem, fundamentally, that I take issue with. 

In the early and mid game it's possible to maintain heroes, the estate, and to progress without too much difficulty, although the game balance really fights you at each turn. It's not an enjoyable experience, and don't get me wrong, I like a challenge and I like having to made trade-offs. Darkest Dungeon's approach to this isn't fun though, certainly not beyond mid-game. It becomes a chore, a grind, and it feels like the higher level dungeons and monsters weren't tuned properly. The game goes from being challenging (with not much in the way of reward either) to being frustrating and incredibly disrespectful of your time invested.

Some people love the punishment.  I do not.  There doesn't actually seem to be all that much to the gameplay itself and success and failure can feel like a complete flip of the coin.  The game absolutely oozes style and atmosphere but that can only carry it so far before your session can become an exercise in relief that you made it through or frustration that the RNG resulted in your party getting rolled and wasting your time.  There are some things you can learn for your next run but the RNG ensures that whether or not you can actually put that knowledge to use is another story.  If you enjoy trial and error and have lots of free time, you might enjoy it.  If your time is more limited and you use games as a bit of escape, you probably want to pass here. Great atmosphere, design, lore, and narration. The combat is initially fun, lots of different party compositions are viable. There is quite a bit of strategy involved in who to bring, and what skills to equip them with. The issue is that this game absolutely does not respect your time. 

You'll spend many many hours grinding up characters on apprentice level, only to repeat the same missions and combats over and over on veteran, and then finally champion. There are very minor additions and tweaks to enemy parties on the higher level dungeons, but ultimately the game is a repetitive slog that turns boring long before you're even close to finishing a single playthrough.
